Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds for the conference "Contemporary Combinatorics 2014", which will be held at the University of Memphis during March 27-29, 2014. The aim of this conference is to bring together a group of outstanding mathematicians who work on topics loosely related to combinatorics, probability and combinatorial number theory so that they can present their latest research results, and also interact with other conference participants, including young researchers and even high school students.

Combinatorics is an area of mathematics that studies discrete structures. It has applications to computer science, chemistry, and many areas of engineering. The conference aims to promote interaction between senior and junior researchers, to allow for the dissemination of recent research results, and to publicize the importance of combinatorics in the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Contemporary Combinatorics 2014 conference, the sixteenth in the Paul Erd?s Lecture Series,  was held in Memphis on March 27-29, 2014 and this year included an additional feature after the conference, Research Students' Day on March 30, 2014, in which students presented their research and recent results. Hosted by the Institute of Combinatorics at the University of Memphis in honor of Erd?s's past relationship with the Institute's founding members, and in continuance of an extremely successful fifteen year tradition of annually bringing together outstanding mathematicians who work on topics in combinatorics, understood in the widest sense, the 2014 Contemporary Conference was a momentous celebration of mathematics. In addition several talks featured industry and academic application of combinatorial techniques.  The poster session and Research Students' Day was also a resounding success as students had a chance to share their blossoming research and get feedback not only from peers but from senior researchers as well.  Many collaborative connections were made on a number of levels.

 

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impact. The Contemporary Combinatorics meeting in Memphis continues to go a great way towards redressing the historical deficit of high level mathematical conferences in the mid-south area. Ideas shared and interactions initiated at these conferences have provided significant foundation for beginning and continuing collaborations, graduate student dissertations, workshops, classes and seminars.

 

Participants and Speakers. Including speakers, there were 115 total participants in the conference. The roster of the speakers included:

  1. Paul Balister, University of Memphis
  2.  Jószef Balogh, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
  3. Vitaly Bergelson, The Ohio State University
  4. Enrico Bombieri, Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton
  5. Tristan Denley, Tennessee Board of Regents
  6. Dwight Duffus, Emory University
  7. Ron Gould, Emory University
  8. Cecilia Holmgren, Stockholm University, Sweden
  9. Alice Hubenko, Eucalyptus Systems, Inc.
  10. Imre Leader, University of Cambridge
  11. Po-Shen Loh, Carnegie Mellon University
  12. Eyal Lubetsky, Microsoft Research, Redmond
  13. Asaf Nachmias, University of British Columbia
  14. Jamie Radcliffe, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
  15. Oliver Riordan, University of Oxford, UK
  16. Tom Trotter, Georgia Institute of Technology
  17. Ramarathnam Venkatesan, Microsoft Research, India
  18. Máte Wierdl, University of Memphis
  19. John Wierman, Johns Hopkins University

 

The Paul Erd?s Lecture is a generally accessible talk given by a highly accomplished, senior mathematician designed for an audience of varying abilities and interests in the general field of mathematics.  This talk is well attended by high school students, undergraduates and others with some interest in the history and culture of mathematics.  This year's talk entitled "Recent Progress on Prime Numbers and Sieves" was delivered by Fields Medalist Enrico Bombieri. It discussed the theory of prime numbers and the fact that it has seen very recently memorable progress with the astonishing solution of the problem of existence of infinitely many prime pairs with bounded gap, obtained independently by Yitang Zhang and James Maynard.  The talk gave a bit of the history of the problem, a description of the progress in obtaining better and better sieving tools and a quick outline of new ideas in the works by Zhang and Maynard.
